claims: We found 15 studies that have investigated or discussed the potential effects of traveller screening, Wuhan’s lockdown, travel restrictions, and contact tracing in China or other countries

Our findings show that NPIs, inter-city travel restrictions, social distancing and contact reductions, as well as early case detection and isolations, have substantially reduced COVID-19 transmission across China, with the effectiveness of different interventions varying

We found that without NPIs, the number of COVID-19 cases would increase rapidly across China, with a 51-fold increase in Wuhan, a 92-fold increase in other cities in Hubei, and 125-fold increase in other provinces, as of February 29 (Table 1)

Our findings show that combined NPIs, inter-city travel restrictions, social distancing and contact reductions, as well as early case detection and isolations, have substantially reduced COVID-19 transmission across China

Although we have shown that the apparent fall in incidence of COVID-19 since CNY’s day in China is likely to be attributed to the interventions taken, we cannot rule out the possibility that the decrease was caused by varying timings and intensities of various NPIs taken in different areas as well as some other unknown seasonal factors, e.g. temperature and absolute humidity.43,44
findings: We estimated that there were a total of 114,325 COVID-19 cases (interquartile range [IQR] 76,776 - 164,576) in mainland China as of February 29, 2020, and these were highly correlated (p<0.001, R2=0.86) with reported incidence
The estimated epidemics and peaks were consistent with patterns of reported data by onset date, with a high correlation (p<0.001, R2=0.86) found across regions (Figure 2)
key_statements: We used epidemiological parameters estimated for the early stage of outbreak in Wuhan to parameterise the transmission before non-pharmaceutical interventions were implemented
We found 15 studies that have investigated or discussed the potential effects of traveller screening, Wuhan’s lockdown, travel restrictions, and contact tracing in China or other countries

Our findings show that non-pharmaceutical interventions, inter-city travel restrictions, social distancing and contact reductions, as well as early case detection and isolations, have substantially reduced COVID-19 transmission across China, with the effectiveness of different interventions varying

People in China were estimated to make close to 3 billion trips over the 40-day Chinese new year travel period from January 10 to February 18, 2020.12,13 A cordon sanitaire of Wuhan and surrounding cities in Hubei Province was put in place on January 23, 2020, just two days before Chinese new year’s day on January 25

Wuhan’s lockdown is likely to have occurred during the latter stages of peak population numbers leaving the city before Chinese new year, with around 5 million people likely leaving before the start of the travel ban, departing into neighbouring cities and other megacities in China.[14]

Adjusted by the level of travel reductions derived from the 2020 dataset where applicable, the second dataset was used to simulate the COVID-19 spread and predict future transmission via population movements under various scenarios, with or without inter-city travel restrictions

Our findings show that combined non-pharmaceutical interventions, inter-city travel restrictions, social distancing and contact reductions, as well as early case detection and isolations, have substantially reduced COVID-19 transmission across China

Three points raised by our findings are important. They support and validate the idea that population movement and close contact has a major role in the spread of COVID-19 within and beyond China,[3,14] indicating the global risk of a pandemic via travellers infected with this virus

As the lockdown of Wuhan happened at the late stage of movement before Chinese new year, travel restrictions did not halt the seeding of the virus from Wuhan, but it likely prevented extra cases being exported from Wuhan to a wider area
The second point is that the importance and effects of various non-pharmaceutical interventions differed
Compared to travel restrictions, improved detection and isolation of cases as well as the social distancing likely had a greater impact on the containment of outbreak
The social distancing intervention reduced contact with people who travelled from the epicentre of the epidemic, who were encouraged to quarantine at home
Given travel and work resuming in China, the country should consider at least partial continuation of non-pharmaceutical interventions to ensure that the COVID-19 outbreak is sustainably controlled

Our model framework accounts for daily interactions of populations, interventions between and within cities, as well as the inherent statistical uncertainty associated with paucity of epidemiological parameters, before and after the interventions

Together with near-real time population movement and case data, our approach can be used for risk assessment for near real-time estimation of the effectiveness of different non-pharmaceutical interventions in the ongoing outbreaks in different countries
Based on sensitivity analyses of multiple parameters, our results on the relative effects of non-pharmaceutical interventions are robust to the possibility of changes in parameters

As our simulations were based on the parameters estimated for the cases found in the early stage of the outbreak in Wuhan, , which might not account for the asymptomatic and mild infections, our study may underestimate the total number of infections
Our findings could be affected by bias and confounding because the modelling is based on observations over a short period

We have shown that the apparent fall in incidence of COVID-19 since Chinese new year’s day in China is likely to be attributed to the interventions taken, we cannot rule out the possibility that the decrease was caused by varying timings and intensities of various non-pharmaceutical interventions taken in different areas as well as some other unknown seasonal factors, e.g. temperature and absolute humidity.[43,44]
Our models and findings were based on some assumptions on parameterizations

If the epidemiological parameters of COVID-19 transmission in other cities across China differed with estimates from the outbreak at the early stage where no non-pharmaceutical interventions were in place in Wuhan, our estimates of the effectiveness of interventions in reducing COVID-19 transmission could be biased

We only measured the main groups of non-pharmaceutical interventions and other interventions might contributed to the outbreak containment, further research is needed to elaborate the effect of each intervention

From a public health standpoint, our results highlight that countries facing potential spread of COVID-19 should consider proactively planning non-pharmaceutical interventions and relevant resources for containment, given how the earlier implementation of non-pharmaceutical interventions could have lead to significant reductions in size of the outbreak in China
The results here provide some guidance for countries as to the likely effectiveness of different non-pharmaceutical interventions at different stages of an outbreak

Suspected and confirmed cases should be identified, diagnosed, isolated and reported as early as possible to control the source of infection, and the implementation of cordon sanitaires or travel restrictions for significantly affected areas may prevent seeding the virus to wider regions

Reducing contact and increasing social distance, together with improved personal hygiene, e.g. hand washing, can protect vulnerable populations and mitigate COVID-19 spread at the community level, and these interventions should be promoted throughout the outbreak to avoid the resurgence
